dt: {bc}any of various abnormal conditions characterized by the secretion and excretion of excessive amounts of urine

et: Middle English {it}diabet, diabete,{/it} borrowed from Late Latin {it}diabētēs,{/it} borrowed from Greek {it}diabḗtēs,{/it} from {it}diabē-,{/it} variant stem of {it}diabaínein{/it} "to stride, walk or stand with legs apart, step across, cross over" (from {it}dia-{/it} {et_link|dia-|dia-} + {it}baínein{/it} "to step, walk") + {it}-tēs,{/it} suffix of agency {ma}{mat|come:1|}{/ma}

The literal sense of Greek {it}diabḗtēs{/it} in relation to the base verb {it}diabaínein{/it} is not entirely clear. The Greek physician Aretaeus of Cappadocia (active ca. 130-40 A.D.), author of a detailed description of diabetes mellitus (in Book 2 of {it}De causis et signis diuturnorum morborum{/it}), takes the name of the disorder as a given, and explains it as a particular application of the word {it}diabḗtēs,{/it} the meaning of which he seems to regard as self-evident. It has been assumed that he alludes to {it}diabḗtēs{/it} in the sense "siphon," referring to frequent urination, as if liquid was being drawn out of the sufferer by a siphon. In the following clause, however, he maintains that moisture ({it}tò hygrón{/it}) does not stay in the body but leaves it "as if by a {it}diabáthrē{/it} ("hókōs diabáthrēi")." The word {it}diabáthra{/it} (Ionic {it}diabáthrē{/it})—also a derivative of {it}diabaínein{/it}—has various attested meanings: "ladder," "gangway," "bridge." The suggestion has been made that "bridge" or "channel" is the most appropriate sense, though the mixing of metaphors is perhaps an indication that the text is corrupt, or that some no longer recoverable sense of the word is in play. (See discussion in Chalmers L. Gemmill, "The Greek concept of diabetes," {it}Bulletin of the New York Academy of Medicine,{/it} vol. 48, no. 8 [September, 1972], pp. 1033-36.)
shortdef: any of various abnormal conditions characterized by the secretion and excretion of excessive amounts of urine; especially : diabetes mellitus

dt: {bc}a disorder of the pituitary gland characterized by intense thirst and by the excretion of large amounts of urine

et: borrowed from New Latin {it}diabētēs insipidus,{/it} literally, "bland diabetes," referring to the lack of sweetness in the urine

Term introduced, along with {it}diabētēs mellītus,{/it} by the Scottish physician William Cullen (1710-90) in {it}Synopsis nosologiæ methodicæ,{/it} editio tertia, tomus II (Edinburgh, 1780), pp. 244-45.
shortdef: a disorder of the pituitary gland characterized by intense thirst and by the excretion of large amounts of urine

dt: {bc}a variable disorder of carbohydrate metabolism caused by a combination of hereditary and environmental factors and usually characterized by inadequate secretion or utilization of insulin, by excessive urine production, by excessive amounts of sugar in the blood and urine, and by thirst, hunger, and loss of weight {dx}compare {dxt|type 1 diabetes||}, {dxt|type 2 diabetes||}{/dx}

et: borrowed from New Latin {it}diabētēs mellītus,{/it} literally, "honey-sweet diabetes," referring to the smell and taste of sugar in the urine
shortdef: a variable disorder of carbohydrate metabolism caused by a combination of hereditary and environmental factors and usually characterized by inadequate secretion or utilization of insulin, by excessive urine production, by excessive amounts of sugar in the blood and urine, and by thirst, hunger, and loss of weight
